message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The activation of the interferon response can lead to decreased viral replication within the cell (A), upregulation of NK cell ligands on the infected cell (C), and activation of NK cells (D). However, a rhinovirus-specific, cell-mediated immune response (B) is less likely to occur as rhinovirus infections mainly elicit a humoral immune response.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The activation of the interferon response leads to decreased viral replication within the cell (A), upregulation of NK cell ligands on the infected cell (C), and activation of NK cells (D), all of which help to combat the viral infection. Option B, a rhinovirus-specific, cell-mediated immune response, is least likely to be an outcome because interferons do not directly stimulate a T cell-mediated immune response.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The activation of the interferon response will lead to decreased viral replication within the cell (A), upregulation of NK cell ligands on the infected cell (C), and activation of NK cells (D). However, interferon response does not directly lead to a rhinovirus-specific, cell-mediated immune response (B), which requires activation of T cells.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The activation of the interferon response can lead to decreased viral replication within the cell (A), upregulation of NK cell ligands on the infected cell (C), and activation of NK cells (D). However, it is unlikely to lead to a rhinovirus-specific, cell-mediated immune response (B), as interferons are not specific to a particular type of virus and instead initiate a broad antiviral response.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Activation of the interferon response leads to increased antiviral activity within the infected cell, as well as upregulation of NK cell ligands and activation of NK cells. However, it does not directly lead to a rhinovirus-specific, cell-mediated immune response, as this would require the action of T cells which are not directly activated by interferons. Therefore, option (B) is least likely to be an outcome of the activation of the interferon response.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The interferon response would lead to decreased viral replication within the cell (option A), upregulation of NK cell ligands on the infected cell (option C), and activation of NK cells (option D). Option B is the least likely outcome as there is no specific cell-mediated immune response directed towards rhinovirus, unlike other viruses such as influenza virus or human immunodeficiency virus. The cell-mediated immune response is generally directed towards virus-infected cells and foreign antigens presented on MHC molecules.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Activation of interferon response will lead to decreased viral replication within the cell, upregulation of NK cell ligands on the infected cell, and activation of NK cells. However, it is least likely to produce a rhinovirus-specific, cell-mediated immune response as interferon response is non-specific and affects various viruses.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The activation of the interferon response leads to increased antiviral activity, such as decreased viral replication, upregulation of NK cell ligands, and activation of NK cells. Option B, a rhinovirus-specific cell-mediated immune response, is not a direct outcome of interferon activation.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The activation of interferon response can lead to decreased viral replication within the cell, upregulation of NK cell ligands on the infected cell, and activation of NK cells. However, it is least likely to result in a rhinovirus-specific, cell-mediated immune response as interferon response is a nonspecific response to viral infection and does not lead to an antigen-specific immune response.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Activation of the interferon response leads to decreased viral replication within the cell (A), upregulation of NK cell ligands on the infected cell (C), and activation of NK cells (D). However, it is unlikely to lead directly to a rhinovirus-specific, cell-mediated immune response (B), as this requires activation of T-cells, which is not directly controlled by interferon. The activation of the interferon response is an early response to viral infection and occurs before the development of adaptive immunity.
